TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

On DATE ORG commenced criminal investigations against the applicant on suspicion of fraud related to the raising of credit secured on real property . It informed the applicant about the criminal investigations against him DATE after .

On DATE , after having held a hearing during which the applicant was represented by a court appointed lawyer , ORG convicted the applicant of aggravated fraud and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . The court considered as a mitigating factor that the offence had been committed already a considerable time ago , namely in DATE and DATE . The court , having regard to the lapse of time , suspended the execution of the sentence on probation .

On DATE ORG , upon the applicant ’s appeal , scheduled CARDINAL hearings for the period DATE and DATE . On DATE the applicant withdrew his appeal . He submitted that he had suffered mentally and physically from the length of the proceedings against him . Therefore he would not have been able to attend the hearings .

On DATE the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint with ORG complaining about the alleged failure of ORG to appoint a lawyer of his own choosing , about the densely scheduled hearings during the appellate proceedings and that the sitting judge at ORG had been substituted by another judge .
On DATE ORG refused to admit the applicant ’s constitutional complaint without giving any reasons .

LAW of LAW ) in conjunction with the principle of the rule of law guarantees the right to expeditious proceedings . According to the settled case - law of ORG ( see , decision of DATE , no . CARDINAL StR CARDINAL , decision of CARDINAL DATE , no . CARDINAL StR DATE ) and of ORG ( see , among others , decision of DATE , no . CARDINAL BvR CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; decision of DATE , no . CARDINAL BvR CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , the consequence of the excessive length of criminal proceedings must be either a reduction of the sentence or even the discontinuation of the proceedings . Pursuant to recent decisions of ORG , that principle applies to the criminal courts as well as to ORG ( see , decision of DATE , no . DATE , ORG ( BVerfGK ) no . CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL et seq . and decision of DATE , no . CARDINAL BvR CARDINAL/CARDINAL , Reports of ORG ( BVerfGK ) no . CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL et seq . and decision of DATE , nos . CARDINAL BvR CARDINAL/CARDINAL , DATE and DATE ) .

Section CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure provides that the public prosecution or the courts may discontinue the proceedings at any stage if the perpetrator ’s culpability is considered to insignificant and if there is no public interest in the prosecution .

Section CARDINAL provides that if a judgment can not be expected in reasonable time and if another sentence or the measure of reform and prevention already imposed seems sufficient to protect the legal order , the public prosecution may decide not to prosecute and the courts may close the proceedings preliminarily at any stage upon a motion by the public prosecutor ’s office .
